required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Pharmacist-led Transitions of Care Program
clinical_study.official_title: The Impact of a Pharmacist-Led Transitional Care Program on Health Outcomes of Uninsured Populations

brief_summary.textblock: This study was to show the value of pharmacists in providing transitions of care to and improving health outcomes of uninsured populations. It also aimed to demonstrate the feasibility of implementing a transitions of care program in an indigent care clinic with limited resources. We hypothesized that a pharmacist-led transitions of care program will reduce 30-day hospital readmission rates among the uninsured discharged from a community hospital.

primary_outcome.description: Whether a study participant had any hospital readmission 30-day post-discharge

secondary_outcome.description: Whether a study participant had any hospital readmission 60-day post-discharge
Whether a study participant had any hospital readmission 90-day post-discharge
Number of ED visits among study participants in each study arm 30-day post-discharge
Number of ED visits among study participants in each study arm 60-day post-discharge
Number of ED visits among study participants in each study arm 90-day post-discharge

secondary_outcome.measure: 30-day follow-up visit with a primary care provider
secondary_outcome.description: Did a study participant keep a follow-up appointment with a primary care provider

arm_group.description: The study participants in this aim received usual care plus medication reconciliation, daily schedule for medication taking and medical condition monitoring, and follow-up phone calls from a pharmacist.
The study participants in this arm received usual care.

intervention.description: The intervention was a pharmacist-led transitions of care program that include medication reconciliation, daily schedule for medication taking and medical condition monitoring, and follow-up phone calls from a pharmacist at 60- and 90-day post-discharge in addition to the usual care.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Aged 18 years old or older
- Uninsured
- English speaking
- Discharged from East Alabama Medical Center within the past 16 days
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who did not show up for the first follow-up visit with the study pharmacist after being referred by the care coordinator at East Alabama Medical Center

link.description: Key Facts about the Uninsured Population
